Award.AwardTitle: Tuning Morphology and Mechanics of Fibrin Assemblies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fibrin is one of a class of fibrous protein materials that exhibit levels of strength, elasticity and toughness that rival current engineering materials. Fibrin fiber networks form the structural framework of blood clots. In recent studies we have found that fibrin fibers can be stretched to over 2-fold and relax to their original lengths, and exhibit very large breaking strain limits, with an average extensibility of over 300%. Additionally, we have discovered a new form of fibrin assembly: the monomolecular sheet. These sheets also exhibit very high strain limits, and self-assemble unsupported over areas of hundreds of square microns. That fibrin is capable of forming mechanically robust assemblies in these distinct morphologies indicates that its polymerization mechanisms are flexible. This is somewhat unexpected behavior for a biomaterial that is optimized for highly specific morphological forms assembled in particular physiological conditions. This protean property of the fibrin molecule suggests that it holds design principles that could be applied to engineered polymeric materials. However, even in fibrin?s standard physiological form, many questions remain regarding its detailed architecture and polymerization dynamics. For the newly discovered fibrin morphologies such as the monomolecular sheet, next to nothing is known of their molecular scale structure, assembly mechanisms, or mechanical properties.
To address these questions, we will pursue two central tracks of investigation: 1. The evaluation and control of morphology, and 2. The evaluation and control of the mechanics of the resulting assemblies. Central to both tracks is the employment of recombinant protein engineering to design and synthesize variant proteins that will enhance or repress specific monomer-monomer interactions as well as lengthen or shortened the putative ?stretchable? regions of the protein. Control over fibrin morphology will be developed through systematic investigation of the effect of biochemical and environmental variables; we will test a range of engineered recombinant fibrin variants as well as fabricate custom nanoscale and microscale sub-structures on which to assemble fibrin. Using nanomanipulation techniques, we will evaluate the stress vs. strain properties of single fibers, investigate the influence that single fiber properties have on fiber networks, and characterize the mechanical properties of the monomolecular sheets. Custom designed protein variants will be employed to tune the stress vs. strain behavior of these assemblies.
Our studies will provide new design strategies for custom tuned mechanical properties coupled with morphological control. Successful completion of this project will produce design principles that, along with directly informing fibrin based materials, will more generally provide new avenues for polymeric materials engineering. Success will also provide a complete picture of the molecular scale details of fibrin mechanics, and will lend new and valuable perspective to healthy as well as pathological blood clotting. Our project also includes an extensive education and outreach component. We will hold public outreach events as well as participate in K-12 student and teacher outreach activities including at least one regional and one national science teacher meeting each year. Each summer, we will recruit 2 students from programs promoting minority recruitment for research.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes

The focus of this project was on the remarkable structural and mechanical properties of fibrin, a polymeric protein material that plays an important role in the mechanics of blot clots.  Fibrin is one of a class of fibrous protein materials that exhibit levels of strength, elasticity and toughness that rival current engineering materials.   In prior studies we found that fibrin fibers are elastic: they can be stretched to over 2-fold and relax to their original lengths, and exhibit very large breaking strain limits, with an average extensibility of over 300%.  Inspired by these results we embarked on new studies to reveal the molecular origins of fibrins properties, as well as explore the potential materials design lessons that fibrin offers. This project resulted in 6 peer reviewed papers, over ten talks at national meetings, five undergraduate projects including one co-authorship in a peer reviewed journal, one PhD project completed and another soon to be completed.

Broadly, our project consisted of two major research areas:

A. To control fibrin structure through systematic investigation of the effect of biochemical and environmental variables.

B. Using nanomanipulation techniques, we evaluated the mechanical properties of the fibrin assemblies including fibers, fiber networks and sheets.

Major Project Outcomes: Intellectual Merit

1. Fibrin Fibers show very rapid re-coil behavior when released from high strain. Using nanomanipulation and high frame rate microscopy we showed that fibrin fibers recoil on ~1ms timescale when released from a highly stretched state. These results and accompanying molecular dynamics simulation results support the view that the molecular origins of fibrins elastic behavior lies not in unfolding and refolding of molecular domains, but uncoiling and recoiling of non-structured protein regions, much as is the case in rubber or other elastomeric materials.  We have published these results in Biophysical Journal:  18 (104), 2671-80 (2013).

2. We have developed a model for the alphaC region of fibrinogen. The structure and function of the fibrin(ogen) αC region has been subject to much debate over the past 40 years. To address these issues, we have developed a model of αC region structure using discrete molecular dynamics modeling in collaboration with Nikolay Dokholian’s group here at UNC. This structure is consistent with the binding and cross-linking requirements of the αC region and also suggests a possible mechanism by which FXIIIa can select residues for ligation. We currently have a manuscript in preparation describing these results. 

3. We have successfully synthesized engineered Hybrid Fibrinogens that provide insight into Fibrinogen polymerization and mechanics. We synthesized a novel fibrinogen that apparently impairs only lateral aggregation. This variant is a hybrid, where the human αC region has been replaced with the homologous chicken region. Our data suggest that HC fibrin monomers can assemble into protofibrils or protofibril-like structures, but these either cannot assemble into fibers or assemble into very thin fibers. We published this work in Biochemistry. 50(42): p. 9066-9075 (2011).

4. We have performed single molecule AFM force spectroscopy experiments revealing the dissociation mechanics and energetics the interactions which drives fibrin polymerization.   The A:a interaction is a crucially important in fibrin polymerization and fibrin structure. Its response to applied forces provides insights into how fibrin fibers respond under the shear loads of the vasculature. We have found, preforming “force clamp” experiments that when force is applied ...

Fibrin is one of a class of fibrous protein materials that exhibit levels of strength, elasticity and toughness that rival current engineering materials. In prior studies we found that fibrin fibers are elastic: they can be stretched to over 2-fold and relax to their original lengths, and exhibit very large breaking strain limits, with an average extensibility of over 300%. Inspired by these results we embarked on new studies to reveal the molecular origins of fibrins properties, as well as explore the potential materials design lessons that fibrin offers. This project resulted in 6 peer reviewed papers, over ten talks at national meetings, five undergraduate projects including one co-authorship in a peer reviewed journal, one PhD project completed and another soon to be completed. Broadly, our project consisted of two major research areas: A. To control fibrin structure through systematic investigation of the effect of biochemical and environmental variables. B. Using nanomanipulation techniques, we evaluated the mechanical properties of the fibrin assemblies including fibers, fiber networks and sheets. Major Project Outcomes: Intellectual Merit 1. Fibrin Fibers show very rapid re-coil behavior when released from high strain. Using nanomanipulation and high frame rate microscopy we showed that fibrin fibers recoil on ~1ms timescale when released from a highly stretched state. These results and accompanying molecular dynamics simulation results support the view that the molecular origins of fibrins elastic behavior lies not in unfolding and refolding of molecular domains, but uncoiling and recoiling of non-structured protein regions, much as is the case in rubber or other elastomeric materials. We have published these results in Biophysical Journal: 18 (104), 2671-80 (2013). 2. We have developed a model for the alphaC region of fibrinogen. The structure and function of the fibrin(ogen) αC region has been subject to much debate over the past 40 years. To address these issues, we have developed a model of αC region structure using discrete molecular dynamics modeling in collaboration with Nikolay DokholianÆs group here at UNC. This structure is consistent with the binding and cross-linking requirements of the αC region and also suggests a possible mechanism by which FXIIIa can select residues for ligation. We currently have a manuscript in preparation describing these results. 3. We have successfully synthesized engineered Hybrid Fibrinogens that provide insight into Fibrinogen polymerization and mechanics. We synthesized a novel fibrinogen that apparently impairs only lateral aggregation. This variant is a hybrid, where the human αC region has been replaced with the homologous chicken region. Our data suggest that HC fibrin monomers can assemble into protofibrils or protofibril-like structures, but these either cannot assemble into fibers or assemble into very thin fibers. We published this work in Biochemistry. 50(42): p. 9066-9075 (2011). 4. We have performed single molecule AFM force spectroscopy experiments revealing the dissociation mechanics and energetics the interactions which drives fibrin polymerization. The A:a interaction is a crucially important in fibrin polymerization and fibrin structure. Its response to applied forces provides insights into how fibrin fibers respond under the shear loads of the vasculature. We have found, preforming "force clamp" experiments that when force is applied to this interaction, a characteristic multi-step "unfolding" process happens before dissociation. We are currently preparing a manuscript for Biophysical Journal that will report these results. 5. We have determined that enzymatic breakdown of fibrin fibers depends on mechanical strain.
